ca.ualberta.cmput301f13t13.storyhoard.dataClasses

Class Media

  • java.lang.Object
    • ca.ualberta.cmput301f13t13.storyhoard.dataClasses.Media

  • public class Media
extends java.lang.Object
    Role: A data class to hold media information. The media can be a photo or an illustration. Instead of holding an actual bitmap as a field, this class holds the path to the bitmap on external memory, and also has a field for the compressed string version of the bitmap (bitmapString) that is the base 64 string version of the bitmap. This is done so we have a way of storing the bitmap information onto the server.

    Also, a media object will always belong to a specific chapter, and no media can belong to more than one chapter.
    Author:
    Stephanie Gil, Ashley Brown

    • Constructor Detail

      • Media

        public Media(java.util.UUID chapterId,
     java.lang.String path,
     java.lang.String type,
     java.lang.String text)
        Initializes a new Media object without needing to specify an id since a random one will be generated on the media's creation. This is what should be used to create a new Media object that is NOT holding search criteria and is NOT being created from data just retrieved from the database.
        Parameters:
        chapterId - Must be a UUID. An example of a UUID's format as a string is:
        "5231b533-ba17-4787-98a3-f2df37de2aD7"
        path - A string that contains the path to the image on the phone's SD card.
        type - The type of Media. The application currently only supports two types: "photo" and "illustration".
        text - Any text associated with the media. This is currently only used for photos, not illustrations, as only photos can carry a text comment with them.

      • Media

        public Media(java.util.UUID id,
     java.util.UUID chapterId,
     java.lang.String path,
     java.lang.String type,
     java.lang.String text)
        Initializes a new media object by specifying its id as the first parameter. Usually used when making a media object that will be holding search criteria since you can specify the id of the media that you would like to search for. When making a media to hold search criteria, any field you don't want to include in the search has to be set to null.

        This constructor is also used to create a new chapter object from data which has been retrieved from the database.

        Example:
        If you want to search for the Media that has the id of "5231b533-ba17-4787-98a3-f2df37de2aD7", you would create the search criteria holding Media objects as follows:
        UUID id = UUID.fromString("5231b533-ba17-4787-98a3-f2df37de2aD7");
        Media criteria = new Media(id, null, null, null, null);
        Parameters:
        id - Must be a UUID. It is the unique identifier of the media object in the database.
        chapterId - Must be a UUID. It is the id of the chapter to which the media belongs to.
        path - A string that contains the path to the image on the phone's SD card.
        type - The type of Media. The application currently only supports two types: "photo" and "illustration".
        text - Any text associated with the media. This is currently only used for photos, not illustrations, as only photos can carry a text comment with them.

    • Method Detail

      • getId

        public java.util.UUID getId()
        Returns the id of the media as a UUID.

        Example:
        UUID chapId = UUID.randomUUID();
        Media myMedia = (chapId, "sd://resources/img1.jpg", "photo", "hi");
        UUID id = myMedia.getId();
        System.out.println(id);

        Output would be something like: "5231b533-ba17-4787-98a3-f2df37de2aD7"

      • getChapterId

        public java.util.UUID getChapterId()
        Returns the chapter id the media belongs to as a UUID.

        Example:
        UUID chapId = UUID.randomUUID();
        Media myMedia = (chapId, "sd://resources/img1.jpg", "photo", "hi");
        UUID newChapId = myMedia.getChapterId();
        System.out.println(newChapId);

        Output would be something like: "5231b533-ba17-4787-98a3-f2df37de2aD7"

      • getPath

        public java.lang.String getPath()
        Returns the path of the media as a String. This indicates where the bitmap associated with the media is stored. It is also assumed the user has not manually deleted or moved the bitmap from its original location.

        Example:
        UUID chapId = UUID.randomUUID();
        Media myMedia = (chapId, "sd://resources/img1.jpg", "photo", "hi");
        String path = myMedia.getPath();
        System.out.println(path);

        Output would be like: "sd://resources/img1.jpg"

      • getType

        public java.lang.String getType()
        Returns the media's type ("photo" or "illustration") as a String.

        Example:
        UUID chapId = UUID.randomUUID();
        Media myMedia = (chapId, "sd://resources/img1.jpg", "photo", "hi");
        String photo = myMedia.getType();
        System.out.println(type);

        Output would be like: "photo"

      • getBitmap

        public Bitmap getBitmap()
        Returns the media's bitmap. It decodes the path that is has stored using the BitmapFactory decodeFile() method. The bitmap is also shrunken before being returned. This is to be able to put it on the server with less of a hassle.

        Example call:
        UUID chapId = UUID.randomUUID();
        Media myMedia = (chapId, "sd://resources/img1.jpg", "photo", "hi");
        Bitmap bitmap = myMedia.getBitmap();

      • getBitmapString

        public java.lang.String getBitmapString()
        Returns the media's bitmap as an encoded String. This method assumes the bitmapString field has already been filled. If not, an empty string would be returned since that is the default value of bitmapString when the media object is initialized.

        Example call:
        UUID chapId = UUID.randomUUID();
        Media myMedia = (chapId, "sd://resources/img1.jpg", "photo", "hi");
        String bmString = myMedia.getBitmapString();

      • getBitmapFromString

        public Bitmap getBitmapFromString()
        Returns the media's bitmap, but does so by converting the bitmapString from string to bitmap. In other words, the path field is not used at all. This method also assumes the bitmapString has been set to something valid, else null will be returned. Note that this is an expensive operation only used when downloading a story from the server since the path variable in that case is useless to us.

        Example call:
        UUID chapId = UUID.randomUUID();
        Media myMedia = (chapId, "sd://resources/img1.jpg", "photo", "hi");
        Bitmap bitmap = myMedia.getBitmapFromString();

      • getText

        public java.lang.String getText()
        Returns the media's text. This is only important for illustrations since users have the option of adding text to the photos they post to annotate a chapter.

        Example:
        UUID chapId = UUID.randomUUID();
        Media myMedia = (chapId, "sd://resources/img1.jpg", "photo", "hi");
        String text = myMedia.getText();
        System.out.println(text);

        Output would be like: "hi"

      • setId

        public void setId(java.util.UUID id)
        Sets the Id of the media. The new Id provided must be a UUID.

        Example call:
        Media myMedia = (chapId, "sd://resources/img1.jpg", "photo", "hi");
        UUID id = UUID.randomUUID();
        myMedia.setId(id);
        Parameters:
        id - New Media id. Must be a UUID or null.

      • setChapterId

        public void setChapterId(java.util.UUID chapterId)
        Sets the Id of the chapter the media belongs to. The new Id provided must be a UUID.

        Example call:
        Media myMedia = (chapId, "sd://resources/img1.jpg", "photo", "hi");
        UUID chapId = UUID.randomUUID();
        myMedia.setChapterId(id);
        Parameters:
        chapterId - New chapter id. Must be a UUID or null.

      • setPath

        public void setPath(java.lang.String path)
        Sets the path to the image file of the Media object. The path will should be a valid path to some file in the phone's SD card.

        Example call:
        Media myMedia = (chapId, "", "photo", "hi");
        myMedia.setPath("sd://resources/img1.jpg");
        Parameters:
        path - String containing valid path to image file.

      • setBitmapString

        public void setBitmapString(Bitmap bitmap)
        Sets the bitmapString of the media. What this is, is the bitmap associated with the Media object, but converted into a base 64 string. If a Chapter has a media, either a photo or illustration, this field is needed filled out when a story is sent to the server since the path becomes useless for stories on the server.

        This method actually takes a bitmap and does the conversion itself using the getStringFromBitmap() method, so no need to do the conversion yourself.

        Example call:
        Media myMedia = (chapId, "sd://resources/img1.jpg", "photo", "hi");
        myMedia.setBitmapString(myMedia.getBitmap());
        Parameters:
        bitmap - Valid bitmap, should never be null.

      • setType

        public void setType(java.lang.String type)
        Sets the type of media the object is. Will either be "photo" or "illustration".

        Example call:
        Media myMedia = (chapId, "sd://resources/img1.jpg", "", "hi");
        myMedia.setType("illustration);
        Parameters:
        type - String saying whether the media is an illustration or photo. You can also use the constant defined within the Media class, example Media.PHOTO and Media.ILLUSTRATION.

      • setText

        public void setText(java.lang.String text)
        Sets the text that goes along with the media. This should only ever be set for a media of type "photo", since only photos contain text comments.

        Example call:
        Media myMedia = (chapId, "sd://resources/img1.jpg", Media.Photo, "");
        myMedia.setText("this is text");
        Parameters:
        text - String containing the text that the user inputed along with his photo.
